1. Start with phonics: Introduce the alphabet and teach children the sounds each letter makes. Once they know the basic sounds, move on to teaching them how to blend sounds together to form words.

2. Sight words: Teach children to recognize commonly used words such as 'the', 'and', 'is', etc. This will help them read faster and more fluently.

3. Read aloud to children: Read to children regularly and passionately. This helps to model good reading habits and to develop a love for reading.

4. Encourage reading: Make sure there are age-appropriate books and reading materials available for children to read. Also, encourage them to read by finding books that interest them.

5. Make reading fun: Use fun games and activities to teach children to read. This may include word games, flashcards, puzzles, and interactive apps.

6. Use repetition: Children learn through repetition, so practise reading with them regularly. It will help build their confidence and fluency.

7. Patience and praise: Be patient with children as they learn to read. Celebrate their achievements and provide positive feedback to encourage them to keep practising.
